list_definition.definition: to face a lot of serious problems or dangers

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The construction project was beset by a range of difficulties.

list_ex_of_english: Both completed two successive presidential terms, a unique accomplishment in the continent, and overcame the political instability that previously beset their nations.
The third period (1946-1974), while beset with difficulties, continued the development started in the second period and made some new innovations, especially in poetry.
It does not guarantee that the host of problems besetting so many countries can be handled effectively.
The president himself preferred to placate the military by forgiving and forgetting the human rights tragedies that had beset his nation.
Since the early 1970s, the region seems to have been widely beset by civil wars, political upheavals, famines and other natural disasters.
Unfortunately, those prepared to consider these aspects are immediately beset with numerous methodological problems.
It is also beset by differences between its members about how to handle problems like unemployment.
Such fatalism comes easily to societies beset by daunting and uncontrollable factors.
